title: Trump Fires Esper as Defense Secretary
summary: President says on Twitter that Christopher Miller has been named acting defense secretary. President Trump dismissed Defense Secretary Mark Esper on Monday, saying in a Twitter post that he had "terminated" his Pentagon chief and replaced him with a new acting secretary, signaling the start of a shake-up in the remaining weeks of the Trump administration.

title: McDonald's to Add 'McPlant' Items, After Test With Beyond Meat
summary: Burger chain revises operations as pandemic persists, increasing emphasis on takeaway orders. McDonald's Corp. is making changes to its menu and restaurant operations as the coronavirus pandemic persists, including an emphasis on to-go orders and new "McPlant" vegetarian items.

title: U.K. Requires Companies to Report on Climate Change by 2025
summary: It is the first country to make disclosures about the business impacts of climate change mandatory. The U.K. said that companies need to report the financial impacts of climate change on their businesses within the next five years, becoming the first country to make the disclosures mandatory as investors and governments demand corporations curb their greenhouse gas emissions.

title: How Vaccines Prove Their Safety
summary: Rare complications will arise, but the public can be confident researchers will get to the bottom of them.. As acute and infectious disease neurologists, we are often asked if a vaccine is safe. Pfizer 's announcement Monday that its Covid-19 vaccine is 90% effective makes the question even more pertinent. Earlier this year, two late-stage clinical trials, from Johnson & Johnson and AstraZeneca , were briefly paused after reports of neurological concerns in individual study participants. Each of these rare instances was carefully scrutinized as an adverse event-a serious clinical observation that requires review by the Data and Safety Monitoring Board.

title: Democrats, Let Progressives Lead
summary: The establishment blows another winnable election, even as Biden wins.. Will there ever be accountability for Democrats? The establishment wing of the party blew one election to Donald Trump and came to the precipice of blowing another. Were there any lessons learned from 2016? Nope. Same guys, same mistakes. The band marches on.

title: Joe Biden's Bitter Harvest
summary: Where might Trump voters have got the idea that a president was illegitimate?. "Let this grim era of demonization in America begin to end." So spoke Joe Biden Saturday night in a speech that was as much a call for unity as a celebration of victory.

title: This Isn't Obama's Middle East
summary: Biden faces new risks and opportunities, with Turkey a rising Islamist threat.. Even in the closing weeks of America's presidential campaign, the grisly murder of French schoolteacher Samuel Paty made an impression. As part of a civics lesson, Mr. Paty showed his class of 13-year-olds the Charlie Hebdo caricatures of the prophet Muhammad. Soon afterward, Mr. Paty was attacked and beheaded in the street. President Emmanuel Macron, whose government has been moving right on law and order as the electoral competition with Marine Le Pen of the National Rally heats up, announced a series of measures aimed at limiting what he called "Islamist separatism."

title: 'American Contagions' Review: Of Policy and Pandemics
summary: During disease outbreaks, constitutional governments afford themselves vast powers. The problem? Giving those powers back.. In July, the Supreme Court declined to block Nevada's Directive 21, the governor's Covid-19 order limiting indoor worship services to "no more than fifty persons," yet allowed casinos and other establishments to gather many more. Dissenting from the court's inaction, Justice Samuel Alito emphasized this palpable discrimination as well as the profound challenge pandemics pose to constitutional government.

title: In My Yard, Every Critter Gets a Handout
summary: Birds, squirrels and more gather for the morning feed. Then I cope with the consequences.. It started with a few slices of leftover bread tossed from our porch. As we closed our weekend house Sunday evenings, I'd give the birds a parting snack. I tore up the crusty pieces into bite-size portions. Over time, a few crows and starlings huddled on the phone line over our yard waiting for us to get on the road. The offering was always gone by the time we returned.

title: Popular Trading Platforms Have Technical Difficulties as Stocks Surge
summary: Companies including Charles Schwab and TD Ameritrade say customers experienced technical problems. Customers of popular online brokerages struggled to trade from their accounts Monday, sidelining many investors who hoped to capitalize on an exuberant market rally that sent stocks soaring.

title: The Covid Vaccine Cavalry
summary: Pfizer brings good news, but watch out for Biden's virus team.. title: ObamaCare Returns to the Supremes

title: Alex Trebek
summary: For 37 years, the "Jeopardy" host offered a 30-minute intellectual reprieve from the consternation of daily life.. Game show hosts aren't usually the subject of editorials, but we'll make an exception for Alex Trebek, the longtime "Jeopardy" host who died Sunday at age 80 after a bout with pancreatic cancer. Millions of Americans will miss the man who presided over a 30-minute cerebral diversion from life's daily consternation.

title: Ex-Astros GM Luhnow Sues Team for Breach of Contract

title: Here's to Ya! (Tuesday Crossword, November 10)
Identity Politics Is Bad Choice for Minorities
summary: Perhaps this election signals that the tide of chronic victimhood is starting to recede and that a message of hope and opportunity will reach the ears of all young people.. Regarding Mike Gonzalez's "Tuesday's Big Loser: Identity Politics" (op-ed, Nov. 5): Nikole Hannah-Jones, creator of the "1619 Project," says she has a problem with Latinos being lumped into one ethnic group. But what about white Americans? We're all lumped together as beneficiaries of "white privilege," even though our backgrounds are no more similar than those of black Puerto Ricans and indigenous Guatemalans. And not all of us grew up privileged.

title: Some Thoughts on Pollsters' Abject Failure
summary: Voters are tired of being labeled and of giving away information that is later used against us.. Regarding "Pollsters Grapple With Another Presidential Miss" (Election 2020, Nov. 5): We voters are tired of being labeled and of giving away information that is later used against us. You ask for our opinion, and we opt not to tell you. You can thank big tech and advertisers for creating a system that is easy to use and highly monetized: pop-up ads, spam and robocalls. There was a time when our information was ours. Now, nationwide campaigns bombard us with incessant questions demanding our opinion on a variety of topics, and every click of the mouse creates a marketing profile on our behalf. We are tired of living under a microscope. We resent efforts to influence our vote months before the election with carefully tailored questions designed to elicit a desired response.

summary: Number of applications so far slides 8%, with tally of applicants down even more, causing uncertainty for schools. This college admissions season is shaping up to be the most uncertain in recent memory for high-school seniors as well as the universities looking to enroll them.

title: On America's Farms, Worries About Regulation, Hope for Trade Deals Under Biden
summary: A Democratic administration raises concerns about potentially stricter environmental regulations; less-combative approach to trade expected. Joe Biden's election as president raises new questions for a U.S. farm sector whipsawed by turbulent years under President Trump.

title: Apple Suspends New Business With Pegatron Over Labor Violations
summary: Taiwanese company said violations involved its plants in Shanghai and Kunshan. Apple Inc. suspended new business with key supplier Pegatron Corp. after finding that the Taiwanese company violated the U.S. smartphone maker's rules related to student worker programs at its China facilities.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Crossing the Line (Monday Crossword, November 9)
Vote Counting Goes On in Many States
summary: Mail and provisional ballots and those sent by military personnel posted overseas remain to be counted. Vote counting goes on in many states, with some too close to declare a winner, even though Democrat Joe Biden clinched enough states to become president-elect, according to the Associated Press tally.

title: Election 2020: What Are the Trump Legal Claims?
summary: The challenges so far are limited in scope and unlikely to produce large vote swings. President Trump and his allies have pledged to intensify legal efforts this week to contest the presidential election. Many of the lawsuits they have filed so far are limited in scope, making them unlikely to produce large vote swings even if successful.

title: Uzabase Agrees to Sell Business News Site Quartz
summary: CEO Zach Seward, Editor in Chief Katherine Bell will buy Quartz from parent company. The co-founder of Quartz and its editor in chief agreed to buy the business news website from Japanese financial data and media company Uzabase Inc., a deal that comes as Quartz has suffered from the economic fallout from the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Biden Charts Course for New Administration
summary: President-elect's transition team reviews series of executive orders that could reverse Trump administration policies. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden forged ahead with his transition to the White House, charting a course for significant policy changes even as President Trump declined to concede the race.

title: Bloomberg's Streaming News Channel Deepens Push in Consumer Media
summary: QuickTake service will cover general interest and lifestyle news, starting with 10-and-a-half hours of daily programming. Bloomberg LP built its multibillion-dollar business selling high-priced data terminals to institutional customers such as financial-services companies. These days, it is focusing much of its energy on reaching media consumers.

title: American Citizen Says He Was Denied Refuge in Hong Kong's U.S. Consulate
summary: California-born pro-democracy activist is facing trial on a charge of unlawful assembly. HONG KONG-An American citizen facing prosecution related to his participation in pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong said he was turned away after seeking protection at the U.S. consulate in the city.

title: What Is Greenwashing? Here Is What Investors Need to Know
summary: As interest in sustainable investing grows, more companies are making misleading claims about their ESG practices. Wall Street professionals increasingly are investing in companies considered to be "green" in that they follow ESG (environmental, social and governance) principles.

title: As Smart-Beta Funds Struggle, Here's What to Do Now
summary: Recent results suggest that these funds have a hard time in turbulent markets. Smart-beta funds, a popular $1 trillion-plus force in the investing world, were supposed to provide investors with a way to consistently beat the broader market by a small amount.

title: Turkey's Erdogan Shakes Up Economic Leadership
summary: Recent exits fuel uncertainty over the direction of Turkey's $740 billion emerging-market economy. ISTANBUL-Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan dismissed the governor of Turkey's central bank, and the country's finance minister announced his resignation, in a surprise weekend shake-up that fueled uncertainty over the direction of an economy caught in deepening currency crisis.

title: New York Congressional Delegation to Be Most Diverse in State History
summary: State will have seven Black members, the largest number in Congress from any state ever. The New York delegation to the House of Representatives will add three Black members next year, including two men who will be the first Black, gay members of Congress.
